facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by WANCHOO, J. on November 28, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. November 28. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-These two petitions challenge the validity of a scheme of road transport service

facts.text: Two petitions challenge the validity of a scheme of road transport service approved by the Government of Orissa under s. 68D(2) of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. November 28. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-These two petitions challenge the validity of a scheme of road transport service approved by the Government of Orissa under s. 68D  2  of the Motor Vehicles Act, No. IV of 1939  hereinafter called the Act .

holdings.text: There is no force in the contention that no hearing was given as required by s. 68D(2) and r. 8; original notice complied, no fresh notice required for adjourned date.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts, we are of opinion that there is no force in the contention raised on behalf of the petitioner. What r. 8 of the Orissa Rules requires is that ten days clear notice has to be given of the time, place and date of hearing to all objectors. This was undoubtedly done, for the date originally fixed for hearing was September 16, 1960. Thereafter the hearing was postponed to September 21 at the instance of the objectors. It was in our opinion no necessary to give a fresh notice giving ten clear days as required by r. 8, for this adjourned date. Rule 8 only applies to the first date to be fixed for hearing. Thereafter if the hearing is adjourned, it is in our opinion unnecessary to give a further notice at all for the adjourned date.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Original 10-day notice served for first hearing date; petitioner absent; adjournment at other objectors' request; r.8 applies only to initial date, no further notice needed.

holdings.text: The Minister was not biased; policy statement in assembly indicates government policy, not personal predetermination; hearsay allegation unsupported by affidavits.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that there is no force in this contention of bias based on this reply of the Minister to a question put in the Legislative Assembly. The Government was asked when it was intending to take over the privately operated motor routes and its reply was really a matter of policy, namely that it was the policy of the Government to take over all the routes eliminating all private operators from April 1, 1961. This did no mean that even if, for example, the scheme was no ready or if the scheme put forth was found by the Government to be open to objection, the Government would still force through the taking over of the privately operated routes from April 1, 1961 This answer was merely an indication of the Governments policy, namely, that the Government was intending to take over all private operated routes from April 1, 1961 but whether in actual fact all the routes would be taken over on that date would depend upon so many circumstances including finance. It cannot be said that this announcement of the Governments policy in answer to a question put in the legislative assembly meant that the Government was determined whatever happened to eliminate all privately operated routes by April 1, 1961. We are therefore of opinion that the Minister cannot be said to be personally biased because this policy statement was made by him in answer to a question put in the legislative assembly. Another reason that is urged to support the personal bias of the Minister is that the Minister is said to have stated to certain persons that as the privately operated routes in the district of Ganjam which was his constituency had been nationalised he was determined to annihilate all the private bus operators in the district of Cuttack also. This allegation has been denied on behalf of the State. It is however urged that no affidavit has been filed by the Minister who alone was likely to have knowledge on this point. It appears however that the petitioners also have no personal knowledge of any such determination on the part of the Minister. Thy based their allegation on an alleged talk between the Minister and two citizens of Cuttack, namely, a municipal councillor and an advocate. No affidavit however of the two persons concerned has been filed to support this allegation. In the circumstances we are of opinion that it was no necessary for the Minister to file an affidavit for the allegation on behalf of the petitioners was also based on heresay and it has been contradicted by similar evidence on behalf of the State. It would have been a different matter if the two persons concerned had made affidavits from personal knowledge. There is therefore no force in this contention and we are of opinion that it cannot be said on the facts of this case that the Minister was biased.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assembly reply reflects policy, not bias; no pre-judgment shown; allegation based on unsworn hearsay from third parties, denied by state without need for minister's affidavit.

holdings.text: Petitioners cannot raise points 3 and 4 (violation of s.68F, r.10 and s.57(2)) for first time in arguments as not pleaded in petitions and no state reply obtained.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the petitioners cannot be allowed to raise these points for the first time in arguments before us, for there is no mention of these points in their petitions. It appears that in an affidavit filed in connection with stay, something was said on these two points but the stay matter was never pursued and never came up before this Court for hearing. In the circumstances there was no reply from the State Government to these allegations. We are of opinion that the petitioners cannot be allowed to raise these points no for the first time in arguments when they did no raise them in their petitions and consequently reject them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No mention in petitions; stay affidavit not pursued; no opportunity for state to reply; procedural bar on new arguments.

holdings.text: Petitioners cannot raise point 4 regarding s.57(2) permit application for first time in arguments as not pleaded.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the petitioners cannot be allowed to raise these points for the first time in arguments before us, for there is no mention of these points in their petitions. It appears that in an affidavit filed in connection with stay, something was said on these two points but the stay matter was never pursued and never came up before this Court for hearing. In the circumstances there was no reply from the State Government to these allegations. We are of opinion that the petitioners cannot be allowed to raise these points no for the first time in arguments when they did no raise them in their petitions and consequently reject them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Same as h3; grouped with point 3.

holdings.text: Final scheme valid; substantial compliance with r.3(vi) as it approves draft scheme (containing date April 1, 1961) without modification, incorporating date by reference.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the rule so read has been substantially complied with, for the notification publishing the final scheme refers to the draft scheme and says that the draft scheme is approved and there is no mention of any modification. In the circumstances it could in our opinion be no unreasonable to read the date April 1, 1961, incorporated in the final scheme by reference to the draft scheme. It would have been a different matter if the draft scheme also did no contain the date of operation. We are therefore of opinion that there has been substantial compliance with r. 3 (vi) , and the final scheme cannot be said to be bad for non-compliance with the rule. We therefore reject this contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Draft had date per rule; final refers to and approves draft sans modification; substantial compliance suffices, date incorporated by reference.

holdings.text: Transport Controller, as chief officer of State Transport Undertaking, authorised to publish draft scheme under s.68C.

anchor.surface_text: There is however no force in this contention, for s. 68C requires that after the State Transport Undertaking has formed the opinion required thereunder and prepared a scheme it shall cause the scheme to be published. The Transport Controller is the chief officer of the State Transport Undertaking and we see nothing irregular if he publishes the scheme prepared under s. 68C. The section lays down that after the scheme has been prepared in the manner provided thereunder, the State Transport Undertaking shall cause it to be published, which means that some officer of the Undertaking will have it published in the gazette. In the present case, the chief officer of the Undertaking has got it published and this in our opinion is in sufficient compliance with s. 68C.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.68C requires STU to 'cause' publication; chief officer (Controller) acting for STU complies.

holdings.text: Argument that s.68C notification shows only personal opinion of Transport Controller, not STU's satisfaction, rejected as not pleaded and question of fact requiring state reply.

anchor.surface_text: We find that this point was also no taken in the petitions. All that was said in the petitions was that the Transport Controller was only in-charge of the transport services in the State and there was no State Transport Undertaking in the State of Orissa within the meaning cl. (b) of s. 68A of the Act. This case has been abandoned but it is no contended is that even though there may be a State Transport Undertaking in Orissa that Undertaking was no satisfied that it was necessary to take action in the manner provided in s. 68C. This in our opinion is a question of fact and should have been specifically pleaded in the petitions so that the State may have been able to make a reply. In the absence therefore of any averment on this question of fact, we are no prepared to allow the petitioners to raise this point in arguments before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not specifically pleaded; earlier related plea abandoned; factual issue needs state reply opportunity.

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Rule 3(vi) Orissa Motor Vehicles Rules support

In the circumstances we reject this companytention also.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts, we are of opinion that there is no force in the contention raised on behalf of the petitioner. What r. 8 of the Orissa Rules requires is that ten days clear notice has to be given of the time, place and date of hearing to all objectors. This was undoubtedly done, for the date originally fixed for hearing was September 16, 1960. Thereafter the hearing was postponed to September 21 at the instance of the objectors. It was in our opinion no necessary to give a fresh notice giving ten clear days as required by r. 8, for this adjourned date. Rule 8 only applies to the first date to be fixed for hearing. Thereafter if the hearing is adjourned, it is in our opinion unnecessary to give a further notice at all for the adjourned date.

This in our opinion is a question of fact and should have been specifically pleaded in the petitions so that the State may have been able to make a reply. In the absence therefore of any averment on this question of fact, we are number prepared to allow the petitioners to raise this point in arguments before us. In the circumstances we reject this companytention also.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that there is no force in this contention of bias based on this reply of the Minister to a question put in the Legislative Assembly. The Government was asked when it was intending to take over the privately operated motor routes and its reply was really a matter of policy, namely that it was the policy of the Government to take over all the routes eliminating all private operators from April 1, 1961. This did no mean that even if, for example, the scheme was no ready or if the scheme put forth was found by the Government to be open to objection, the Government would still force through the taking over of the privately operated routes from April 1, 1961 This answer was merely an indication of the Governments policy, namely, that the Government was intending to take over all private operated routes from April 1, 1961 but whether in actual fact all the routes would be taken over on that date would depend upon so many circumstances including finance. It cannot be said that this announcement of the Governments policy in answer to a question put in the legislative assembly meant that the Government was determined whatever happened to eliminate all privately operated routes by April 1, 1961. We are therefore of opinion that the Minister cannot be said to be personally biased because this policy statement was made by him in answer to a question put in the legislative assembly. Another reason that is urged to support the personal bias of the Minister is that the Minister is said to have stated to certain persons that as the privately operated routes in the district of Ganjam which was his constituency had been nationalised he was determined to annihilate all the private bus operators in the district of Cuttack also. This allegation has been denied on behalf of the State. It is however urged that no affidavit has been filed by the Minister who alone was likely to have knowledge on this point. It appears however that the petitioners also have no personal knowledge of any such determination on the part of the Minister. Thy based their allegation on an alleged talk between the Minister and two citizens of Cuttack, namely, a municipal councillor and an advocate. No affidavit however of the two persons concerned has been filed to support this allegation. In the circumstances we are of opinion that it was no necessary for the Minister to file an affidavit for the allegation on behalf of the petitioners was also based on heresay and it has been contradicted by similar evidence on behalf of the State. It would have been a different matter if the two persons concerned had made affidavits from personal knowledge. There is therefore no force in this contention and we are of opinion that it cannot be said on the facts of this case that the Minister was biased.

This in our opinion is a question of fact and should have been specifically pleaded in the petitions so that the State may have been able to make a reply. In the absence therefore of any averment on this question of fact, we are number prepared to allow the petitioners to raise this point in arguments before us. In the circumstances we reject this companytention also.

anchor.surface_text: There is however no force in this contention, for s. 68C requires that after the State Transport Undertaking has formed the opinion required thereunder and prepared a scheme it shall cause the scheme to be published. The Transport Controller is the chief officer of the State Transport Undertaking and we see nothing irregular if he publishes the scheme prepared under s. 68C. The section lays down that after the scheme has been prepared in the manner provided thereunder, the State Transport Undertaking shall cause it to be published, which means that some officer of the Undertaking will have it published in the gazette. In the present case, the chief officer of the Undertaking has got it published and this in our opinion is in sufficient compliance with s. 68C.

This in our opinion is a question of fact and should have been specifically pleaded in the petitions so that the State may have been able to make a reply.
